title: Concussions in the NFL
text: Is the concussion crisis and CTE the end of the NFL?

comments.text: Football and other kinds of aggressive sports should be replaced by sports focusing more on cooparative aspects and social competences.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ich denke Football wird noch lange ein wichtiges Spiel sein.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Lots of professional sports cause long term injuries. Such as soccer, tennis, boxing ecetera. Isn't sport supposed to be healthy?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A life without football is like a salad without dressing, sad and boring
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Donald Trump requires low intelligence voters to survive as a politician
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football is a beautiful sport and such issues will solve themselves with time.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: “tribal”. that's exactly what’s wrong with football. folks way too willing to get high on tribal experiences. small spectacles - yay!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: football may indeed be “too big to fail”. but so are banks, quote unquote. probably both need taking down a peg - or several pegs?

comments.text: To most of the world "football" is what Americans call soccer

comments.text: As long as everyone is aware of the impacts, they should be allowed to make their own decisions.

comments.text: I don't think so.  It's probably more the possibility of going to a good school.

comments.text: Voting on statements about football adds nothing to my understanding of the issue of concussions in sport.

comments.text: Football... how can it be safer but also retain what makes it interesting?

comments.text: More provision should be given to homeless people in the design of public space.

comments.text: Football sucks. Get rid of it.

comments.text: Je préfère m'informer des nouvelles mondiales sur la TV que sur Internet
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football isn't inherently dangerous (see flag football) but the current ruleset does not prioritize player safety enough.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The helmets should be much larger and more padded.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Should we really be "normalizing" the fact that the NFL has neurologists on site at games.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I would never consent to risks once I'm aware of the negative consequences.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Some people thrive on risks, even when they know the consequences of their actions.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I didn't play or watch football as a child and, look, I'm a high-functioning adult.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Why don't we join the rest of the world and play soccer
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I played football and suffered concussions.  Football should be banned in high school and colleges.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It's not our right to tell people what to do, only inform them of the consequences.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Needs people's regulation. Support will come believing football has good values. Right now it is just another piece of capitalistic world
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Future generations will likely look back on football as a relatively barbaric and unenlightened pastime.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Personally, I don't like watching people injure themselves, so I usually choose to avoid it.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Yes, it will change the game. The solution is to make helmets soft on the outside, to discourage the use of the helmet as a weapon.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: dfsfdsgsdfgdfs dfg dfsg   sdfgsdfg dsfg sd fg sdf
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football is ingrained in American culture. It won't change for a long, long time -- if ever.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In NZ (All Blacks) referees, game rules (by age), training equipment and techniques are continually evolving in response to this news.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football as it stands now needs reform from independent authorities
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I could never imagine allowing my children to play football.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: To me football players are sort of modern gladiators!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Yellow color is associated with warmth.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think Hillary Clinton would be a great president. She may not be the change I want, but she'll be the person to continue the good parts of the Obama presidency.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It's just too bad that these injuries don't occur early enough to prevent football players from breeding.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Guns are a part of our culture despite the frequent and horrific examples of their destruction. American Football will never fade because of its violent characteristics as long as we have guns.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: My history of sports concussions makes it difficult to make meaningful contributions in online dialogue when I'm limited to only 200 characters or less.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: "Girls suffer sports concussions at a higher rate than boys. Why is that overlooked?" -WP 2/10/15. So the football players beat up Gladwell in high school. He didn't care about girls back then either.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It's an overused word, but this CTE revelation is a bombshell. It turns out that Russian roulette has better odds than a football career.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Full grown men running full speed into each other is going to cause physical and mental harm regardless of the advances in safer equipment.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football will get past this. We're not going to ban boxing (a sport *solely* concerned with inflicting head injuries)
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test test
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I'm excited to watch the Seattle Seahawks in the superbowl, not too concerned about the injuries.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Why didn't Malcolm Gladwell warn me that I'd get a long-term knee injury from running in high school, just like many, many other young people do. He's clearly latched onto one topic, with haphazard regard for its context. He's almost exactly the definition of a troll!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We already feel sorry for all the poor people who will keep playing this horrible, horrible sport, don't we.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tackle football should not be a high school sponsored activity
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think the bigger issue will be socioeconomic; poorer folks will be more willing to take the risk for our own amusement. I do feel troubled by this morally as someone who enjoys watching football.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Considering I've read 4 of his books I'm hesitant to say this, but I think Gladwell's commentaries on sports, and the "10,000 hour rule," have already unravelled. His "rule" has been utterly debunked, so you can imagine it doesn't apply to youth hockey as he tried to demonstrate in Outliers. From this video, he not only thinks boxing "disappeared," but he's also never heard of MMA apparently. Football and the lot have always been known as very dangerous sports.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Gladwell calls football a "moral abomination," but I think the real abomination is how he picks one sport without contextualizing the ENTIRE community health risk posed by ALL sports. Ex: so far I haven't heard him mention the rate of concussions of girls heading 70 mph soccer balls. The rules in college and pro football have changed to better protect QBs and receivers. I think Gladwell put down his crumpet to watch football for 1 second and didn't like what he saw. He's an atrocious sports fan.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The monetary incentives of professional football will continue to attract players for a long time, particularly from low income populations.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I played football in high school
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tackle football should not be a school sponsored activity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I'm still going to watch football.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I will not let my kids play.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: This is one of many aspects of American life in which individuals do not pay enough attention to their own well-being and/or fail to protect others from sources of harm.  We infuse our food and homes with toxic chemicals, and we eat junk and drink beer while watching young men destroy their bodies and minds.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football isn't going anywhere. However, parents are going to increasingly not let their kids play the sport, because of the danger involved. In the years ahead, football is going to have a recruiting problem.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football isn't going anywhere anytime soon. However, in much of the country, parents are going to increasingly not want their kids to play the sport. Football is about to have a recruiting problem in the years ahead.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Why do college football coaches get paid $5m per year and the Top Physics Professor in the world gets paid less than $500k? I think if this was reversed we'd see some big changes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football is a proxy for and plays a practical role in averting war.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I will not let me kids play. I'm also still watching football. I'm not sure what that says about me.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text:
You need to say this out loud and think about it for a minute to let it sink in.

The NFL just admitted that 1/3 of all NFL players will develop cognitive problems resulting from brain damage.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It's an overused word, but this CTE revelation is a bombshell. It turns out that Russian roulette has better odds than a football career. This southern conservative remains glad that he didn't let his strapping sons play football.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football *absolutely* has a compelling narrative, just not to Gladwell. Jacked guys, pretty girls, tribal enthusiasm & beer may not play on the upper west side, but it sure does most places.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The NFL has shown that it is taking the issue seriously - they have Neurologists watching the field with binoculars at every stadium. Let's move on and let them take care of it.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The point is that if *RICH* parents have this knowledge from watching PBS documentaries and reading Bloomberg & The New York Times, football will be a sport populated by poor athletes who aren't aware of the risks.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Football will get past this. We're not going to ban boxing (a sport *solely* concerned with inflicting head injuries - and millions of kids still play. There will always be a pool of willing players and that's a good thing for those of us who love watching the sport.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: This is beginning of the end for football as we have known it.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Thank you to Frontline and ESPN for "League of Denial." Without the exposure from this documentary earlier this year, these conditions would continue to take a backseat to the NFL's full-court "no comment" press.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: And these brain injuries are just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the deleterious impact of football on the human body.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I played football when I was a kid, and loved it.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text:
Here's a start - let's not have seven year-olds playing tackle football. Start tackle with high school. 

I can't resist saying that I played football through all of my high school and college days. As a small running back I cherished the praise from coaches when I made a few extra yards by lowering my shoulder (head) and smashing full force into the tackler.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Fantastic sums of money, adulation and fame. That's why anyone would consider being a professional football player. A better question is why should the rest of us care if they scramble their brains?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: They can play football all they want but my child won't and I am not going to worry about changing anyone else's mind because football is so ingrained here it will be 20 years before anything changes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: If I sent this article to fellow parents I would get a very angry and defensive response. They would also say their kids are learning "heads up" football so they don't get hurt.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: As legal adults who are passionate about a game they excel at, they are choosing this path. I doubt that many of them would appreciate you taking this choice away from them, even if you think you know what is best.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Just as the public health campaign against smoking has been a long and eventually successful one, the campaign to end or severely diminish the role of professional football in our society will take a generation or two.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Hopefully the NFL will work to prevent injuries while keeping the game entertaining.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Let's develop a code of safety for kids' football & be smart, not hysterical.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The damage caused by playing football is becoming more and more analogous to the damage caused by smoking, and the reaction by the moneyed interests is exactly the same--denial
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text:
The popularity of football continues to grow despite the known dangers. A third of players developing problems related to increasingly hard impacts is a substantial figure. With so many children going through Pop Warner, high school and college leagues, the line of competition for these coveted and dangerous professional positions will also continue.

Full grown men running full speed into each other is going to cause physical and mental harm regardless of the advances in safer equipment.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Gladwell is a flamethrower and loves to watch the internet burn.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I love football but how can you not agree with Gladwell?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I agree with Gladwell. Boxing and its variations (e.g., Kickboxing) need to be banned as well.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: If you were to ask anyone in the NFL, "is it possible to sustain life altering injuries playing in the NFL?" they would answer "Absolutely yes." This new research doesn't change anything.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We should still be able to engage in things with downsides if we understand what those downsides are.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Gladwell commenting on sports is like Terrell Owens commenting on classical lit.
comments.author: Anonymous
